FORWARD ACKNOWLEDGEMENT

In presenting this Souvenir to you, we will bring many of our leaders and

helpers between whom no discrimination is made.

We voice the sentiment of those of.the Convention; when we tell you that

this setting of the

Convention-is-the- . 17th consecutive year of the Women's

International Convention, May

10-1- 4,

1967- -

We are assembled here in Denver, Colorado:

To thank God for the growth in advancement of membership.

To meet the unmet needs of the world as much as possible.

To learn and put in practice ways of serving the church.

Our challenge is to search for ways to publish the work in fields of tension,

and serve as instruments of God's love, and to serve as leaven within our know-

ledge. We mean to commit ourselves to a continuous growth in the Wisdom and

Knowledge of God. We

want to advance in unity with all of the people of God.

We want to remain as obedient persons in God's plan for His whole world.

We mean to keep a continous growth in the culture of God. We mean to keep

committed to Him our individual lives, to come in unity with all Christians. We

are bowed in obesience to God, that He, has blessed us to carry on this great

Calvacade under the Banner of which it was born.

A. McK.

We have come from our homes, and churches of the United States

to this

great indescribable (In words of Good)

We feel that

and Savior. Welcome is a very common word, seemingly, yet is very important,

WOMEN'S INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION - 1967, DENVER, COLORADO 10

DEDICATION

TO THE

17TH ANNUAL WOMEN'S CONVENTION

GREETINGS TO DR. ANNEL. BAILEY

Jehovah rested from all his work on the seventh day, and yet he had made not woman! In making her he seems to have begun again! Does

Omniscience have afterthoughts? Could this lovely being not have been brought within the seven days? Consider it as a deed which makes

a space for itself so special as to have a separate numbering in the catalogue; yes, as to be itself the beginning of a catalogue, renowned

and immortal. 0 woman, love thy Creator! Thou art the most wonderful instrument he made in the earth; for ever let the work of thy life be

completely given to his holy name.

Dr. Bailey: What builders women can be; encouraged from the fact that Ephraim's daughter Sherah built the nether and upper

Beth-horo- n

( I

Chro. 7:24 ) - What character they can build in their sons and daughters! What influence they can build around themselves, as, a beacon

light amid on-com- ing

darkness.

Women can do a work which men dare not attempt. Although few can follow their circumstances,

to build up a great church, a sweet home,

turning dependent lives toward intelligence, justice, patriotism, and religious fidelity in the grand old Church of God in Christ.

Dr. Bailey:

- A woman can work miracles by her graciousness. She knows how to enter the sick chamber noiselessly, without disturbance,

or ostentation, woman can speak the gentle word, portray the gracious look, and use the magical touch of friendship and trust. In short, she

weaves her own tapestry without appearing to do so by the very force of tenderness. As the head of a dedicated Humanitarian Organization,

we want for you the might of light, the stratagem of love, the courage of faith, your continual progress, and the words of deliverance. The

work of you and women in various parts of the world is above all praise.

We see in you the good woman that "stretcheth out her hand to the poor:" she is a friend and sister

to the poor; she has something for

those who have nothing. In your world

out-reac- h,

the work is a treasure-hous- e on behalf of the unfortunate; the more she has the more the

poor have.

Such a woman is a mother of the world. Evermore will the world need such a mother,

to nurse it in sickness and comfort it in all darkness

of sorrow. Now we have a woman drawn in

full-lengt-

h with the skill of heaven and the feeling of love in Dr. Bailey. By this standard may

women measure themselves;

in this mirror may women see themselves; this is the ideal woman, the real woman; not as seen in any one

individual, but as totalized in the women's work of the Church of God in Christ.

As the dawn on the breaks seventeenth Annual Women's Convention we behold the rising of the women of the Lord, bringing light and in-

spiration to our waiting hearts. As we view

life and immortality, we look for new interpretations of the meaning of life itself. May the yearn-

ing of the ages have its fulfillment in this great session.

BISHOP M.

J. BRADFORD

B9

The acceptance of our invitation to have you come to our city for your convention this year received a joyful response when the news

reached us. To be able to

enjoy

the staunch leadership of your pride; to be able to catch the inspiration from your course of activities;

to

be able to share in the great fellowship that this great body will lend; and in the songs, prayers, addresses,

and other activities will give

us more than we can return. On behalf of those who represent this organization in our city, as well as our friends,

I

bring you words of

welcome.

With humble spirits and generous hearts we are over zealous that nothing will be over looked that might serve to show how glad

we are that you came. The anticipation of your coming has given us strength and desire

to spare no pains in preparation. We welcome you

to share in what we term our personal hospitality.

We welcome you knowing the type of personalities represented in this August body of

well disciplined citizens.

We feel highly honored as having you as our guest we therefore beg of you to accept what we have to offer with

the same spirit we offer it, then there will be a happy group assembled to meet God here and fulfill the promise to carry on. And from agroup

who knows and loves God and its fellowman, we say the honor is ours to have you here, and will be so happy if you will find time to come

back

again.

I, therefore, the State Bishop of the Jurisdiction of Colorado, with State Mother J.

V. Boyd, and other State Officials, District

Overseers, District Missionaries,

and laity, and friends say you are wlecome.

Wm. Byron Odom, State Bishop Colorado

WOMEN'S INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION - 1967, DENVER, COLORADO 15

THE MODERN MESSAGE OF THE BIBLE

"Every scripture inspired of God is also profitable for teaching, for reproof, for

correction, for instruction which is in righteousness"

(

2 Timothy

3:16 ASV )

1.

THE MESSAGE OF SALVATION

In 2 Timothy 3:16, Paul says two things about the Scriptures. One is that they

are inspired of God; the other is that they are profitable. He says that they are

profitable for teaching, for reproof, for conviction, for instruction in righteousness.

He has just reminded Timothy that the Scriptures are able to make one wise unto

salvation.

We should keep in mind the reason Paul gives for his statement that the Scrip-

tures are profitable. It is because they are inspired of God. No other literature is

inspired as are the Scriptures.

The modern message of the Bible is a message of salvation. The world today

needs to know how to be saved. First, last, and all the time, the Bible is meant

to tell us about

Jesus

Christ as our Saviour whom we must trust if we are to be

saved from our sins.

We are grateful for our International President Ann L. Bailey, who gives us the

message of Holiness, or Salvation, that which the whole world needs to know.

Our admonition to our Mother of this massive Calvacade is: Viz. Though dis-

couragement may come, there is nothing to be compared with the joy that you

are going to receive.

Bishop Bailey, Mobile, Alabama

HISTORY

The first Setting of The Convention was held in Los Angeles, California, the Emmanuel Church

of God in Christ 33rd. and Compton Sts., Bishop Samuel

P. Crouch, Pastor.

May 5th 1953

The following Resolutions, and Recommendations, were accepted as the object of The Convention

by the Conventional Body.

In order to create, maintain

and extend to people whom we serve a means by which more amicable

relationship in various phases of human life may be brought into being, we purpose and submit

the following recommendations.

I

That we shall persistently deny the horrors of bloody warfare and violence in human relatbnship,

while at the same time we shall give moral spiritual and material assistance to those agencies

which are seeking in spite of the present crisis, to bring about PEACE.

WQMBN' S INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION - 1967, DENVER, COLORADO IS

II

That we shall endeavor to spread through prayer, unity of purpose and spirit cooperative intel-

lectual, economic and spiritual enterprise, the rich benefits of the Christian Religion to peoples

in our nation, throughout the world. In this connection, we further

recommend that training be

given to the unmarried whom we serve, to fit them to become responsible partners in family living.

Ill

We recommend that efforts be made to encourage Academic training that is not contradictory to

the principles of the christian faith, and to discourage that training that puts the Student of Con-

flict with these Christian principles.

That we seek to increase

through united efforts our Educational facilities.

That our Educational Program include training to strengthen the principles of Democracy as

against Communism.

IV

As Christian Women who believe in the word of God as a Foundation for Democracy, we recom-

mend that our vigilance will never cease until the blight of discrimination be eradicated from our

fair land. To this end we will cooperate with any and all organizations within the framework of

our AMERICAN GOVERNMENT - who are seeking equality, justice and integration of all Amer-

icans into the Democratic way of life.

V

That we seek to foster more wholesome, culture and

inter-cultur- al relationship by calling upon

those persons who are captioned Christian to put into action those principles of the Christian

Faith which emphasize the BROTHERHOOD of man.

VI

That we shall emphasize, by practical example the prime significance of religious life in the

home, and seek to make our world better by making our homes better.

VII

We recommend that careful study be made of sound relationship of learning and spending and

purpose to dissimulate LITERATURE

that our Women might be mobilized to exercise care in

economics of their home life.

VIII

We recommend that telegrams be sent to those who recognized us in the Organizing of this Wo-

men's

Convention.

We further recommend that telegrams will at all times be sent to The President

of the United States, Congressmen, and Senators who are dedicated to the task of

Law-makin- g

for the well being of the people of the United States and consequently the peoples of the World.

IX

We recommend that Lillian Brooks Coffey, Our

FOUNDER-PRESIDENT-b- e

heartily commended

for This CONVENTION

and for the CHRISTIAN manner and

NOBLE LEADERSHIP

which she

has given.

Respectfully submitted,

A BRIEF STATEMENT OF FACTS OF THE BEGINNING OF THE CHURCH OF GOD IN CHRIST IN COLORADO

In the Year 1917, the beginning of the Holiness Movement sprang up in the Southern part of the State among our group, where there were

Spiritual awakenings among the people. Groups met together in prayer revival services. They fasted, prayed, tarried, and searched the

Scriptures, seeking for that genuine spiritual power, in the Pentecostal experience according to Acts 2:4, 10:44, 19:6.

Mother E. L. Jones, her husband and daughter Fay, who had served with the late Bishop D. Bostic of St. Louis, Mo. moved to Colorado in

1917.

Her husband worked the coal mines in the Southern part of the state, as the services were being blessed and the crowds increased the

mining company furnished a building where they could hold their services

in a town called Segunda, Colorado, there Souls were Sanctified

and received the Baptism of the Holy Ghost.

Elder C. E. Morgan with his family moved from Hot Springs, Ark. to Colorado Springs in 1918 at the request of his Mother who was already

a resident of Colorado Springs. It was there that he organized and built the first Church of God in Christ in the state. Churches began to

spread rapidly through the southern half of the state. Elder E. M. Morris was carrying on services in Pueblo and in 1920 he organized the

Church there. The first State Convocation was held there in Pueblo August 1922. The same year thereabout Elder J. E.Morris was ap-

pointed the first State Overseer.

Elder L. J. Douglas organized the first Y. P.

W. W. and was the first President. Elder Douglas also wrote and made up the first Y. P. W. W.

Topics for the State.

Many visitors were attracted

to the state

-- -

among them were, Elder S. M. Crouch, Elder W. B. Holt, Elder E. E. Hamilton,

W. H. Herring,

Mother Tucker. Elders E. L. Fainer and E. Farrell were resident ministers, who were instrumental in assisting Elder D. D. Burger, who

together with a band of baptized saints organized the first Church of God in Christ in Denver, the year 1922.

It was in

these services on Labor Day, the first Monday in September 1922, that Brother Wm. B. Odom was sanctified and the first Sunday

in January 1923 he received the Baptism of the Holy Ghost. The 23rd day of January of the same year, he was given Ministers Liscense.

After serving with these saints a short time, he was called to West Denver where he preached out and organized the Second Church of God

in Christ in Denver in 1924. Since that time, Brother Odom has had an unbroken record of Pastorial Ministry.

A record of those who served as Overseer and Bishop of the State

WHAT ADAM MISSED.

DAM never knew what twas to be a boy, He never swung upon his father's gate,

To wheedle pennies from a doting sire, Or slept in sunshine on the cellar door,

With which to barter for some pleasing toy, Nor roasted chestnuts at the kitchen grate,

Or calm the rising of a strong desire Nor spun his humming top upon the floor.

To suck an orange. Nor did he

He ne'er amused himself with rows of bricks,

E'er cast the shuttlecock to battledoor;

So set, if one fall, all come down ;

Nor were his trousers ever out at knee,

Nor gazed delighted at the funny tricks

From playing marbles on the kitchen floor.

Of harlequin or traveling circus clown.

He never skated o'er the frozen rill,

When winter's covering o'er the earth was By gradual growth he never reached the age

spread ; When cruel Cupid first invokes his art,

Nor ever glided down the slippery hill, And stamps love's glowing lesson, page by page,

With pretty girls upon his trusty sled. Upon the tablets of a youngling's heart.

"From Every State Mother'

A half century, is a short span of time in the history of the world of Christianity, and even in the life of an individual, but length of years

does not necessarily mean deeds or indicate achievement.

Unlimited praise is due, and grateful thanks is given to our President Anne Bailey whose earnest endeavors, and loyal devotion, have

been made, even before she was made President

of the Calvacade, which she now leads.

Anne Bailey has been as now for a period of years, a valiant Soldier, going through the Gates, preparing the way for the people. She has

assisted

in bui Iding up the Highway -

gathering out stones, and lifting up a standard for God's people.

In our minds we view the past, which is for remembering and for rejoicing over goals achieved, and victories won. It is only a foreshadow-

ing of what the present is, and what the future may be. The tomorrow beckons toward new goals, new endeavors, new needs, and new un-

tried ways. These are bewildering, fascinating, compelling tomorrows, but we confidently believe that Anne Bailey

- will meet the challenge,

of the future with renewed faith, with deeper understanding and by seeking new ways to witness and serve and will continue to commit

herself fully to God's mission in His world.

GOD'S ORDER FOR EVANGELISM

The command "to the Jew fisrt"

( Romans 1:16 ) has to do with order, not preference. It does not mean that the Jew is better than the

Gentile or that he deserves Christ as Saviour one bit more, for neither does; but one must begin somewhere. In fact, Peter showed as much

astonishment

in learning that the Gospel was taken to the Gentiles, as some Gentiles taday show in being told that the Gospel is to be

taken to the Jews.

Scripture reveals that God

is

a God of order. This we observe in the creation of the Universe, and His plan of salvation. The same holds

true for evangelism. God's order to "the Jew" is first, and also to the Greek ( Gentile ). It has absolutely nothing to do with showing

favor to the Jew only, for all need the Gospel. It

is prescribing order to assure that His ancient Israel will not be neglected.

How else can we explain the sweet blessing that falls upon those who follow the mandate ( Law

) that was laid down for us' How else

can we account for the happiness that comes to believers when they to a Jew, or any else that Jesus is the Messiah7

We are admonished to be instruments for teaching the Gospel to everyone. The Gospel is a worldwide work, reaching for Christ. Your prayer:,

and fellowship are needed. The promise of Genesis 12:3 will bring you much personal blessing. Try it and see.

MOTHER IDA B. MARTIN

IF I COULD SPEAK AS AN ANGEL

If we could speak the language of men and angels too, and have no love, I am

the same as a rattling pan or a clashing cymbal. If we should have all of the

gifts, and know all secret truths, and knowledge in its every form, and have

perfect faith that we could move mountains, But have no love, I am nothing.

If we should dole out everything for charity and give our bodies up to torture

in mere goasting pride, But have no love, we get from it no good at all.

Love is so patient and so kind: love never boils with jealousy; It never boasts,

is never puffed with pride-

-

It does not act rudely, or insist

upon its rights. It

does not get provoked, never harbors evil thoughts, Is never glad when wrong

is done, But always glad when truth prevails; It bears up under anything, It

exercises faith in everything, It keeps up hope in everything,

LOVE NEVER FAILS

It gives us power to endure in anything

LOVE NEVER FAILS

If there are prophecies, they will be set aside; If now exist estatic

speakings

they will cease If there is knowledge, it will soon be set aside; For what we

know is incomplete, and what we prophecy is incomplete, But when perfection

is come what is imperfect will be set aside.

LOVE NEVER FAILS

When I was a child

-

I talked like a child

-

I thought like a child, When I became

a man, I laid aside childish ways. For now we see a reflection in a looking glass

But then we shall see face to face. Now what "I"

know is "Imperfect", But

then I shall know perfectly as God knows me, So the three FAITH, HOPE, AND

LOVE, endure.

But The Greatest of these is "LOVE". Corinthians 13.

This tho't dwells with me:

By grace we are saved thro' faith and that not of ourselves: it is the gift of God. All as of grace, all is free gift, or we could have no

in-

terest in it. Thanks be to God, for His unspeakable gift of His Son, Jesus Christ, given for a Covenant of the people. Thanks be unto God

for the gift of faith, by which we know this Covenant, and have become so

interested

in Him as the salvation of our souls. Thanks be to

God, for life to work for new principles and new motives, new desires, new hopes,, new fears, and in some measures new conduct.AII of

grace and to the God of grace be all the glory.

Let not the wise glory in wisdom not let the mighty glory in might, let not the rich glory in

riches; but let all that glorifieth, glory in this

God that, understandeth, and knoweth me that is the Lord, which exercise righteousness, loving kindness and judgement in the earth. For

the Lord delights

in these things. Jeremiah 9:23.

God has given us the chance to learn by the word, by observation, and by experience, that all flesh is as grass, and all glory of man, is

as flowers of grass, yet that glory useless, and pretty soon the roots of those flowers are contacted by worms of sin, and they are in a

dying condition. My advice to all is to let grace supplant the roots of your selfish "glory". Give all glory to God, and His perfectly staid

covenant. You will he so happy to know God, that He is the Lord, that exercises righteousness, lovingkindness, and judgement in the

earth.

Dare we that have accepted Him, deny that worms, as we were, know Him now, as a forgiving Saviour, who loves and keeps us. Give your

all to Christ, become one of the Covenant of grace which is summed up in Him. And in this Covenant, you have eternal life that God has

given thro' His Son.

The woman did whaf she could: Painfully misunderstood by others, Mary went on doing her best. It is an easy thing to criticize.

We do it

too freely.

It-i- s difficult to try, to despite criticism, to do our best day after day.

Mary wanted to do something. The woman who lives in this great world of opportunity, and need, and does nothing will have need to tremble

when she at last stands in the presence of Jesus. Mary was not satisfied to live and die on flowery beds of ease, while the kingdom was

so badly in need of servants.

The great drawbacks in our churches today are not found in people incompetent but those who are unwilling to do anything. They are so

busy flying about here and there on silly social tasks that they have no inclination or time to give Christ.

There were doubtless a great many things which Mary could not do. Perhaps she was not fitted by nature to do speech-makin- g.

Possibly

she could not have presided over a meeting. But she could slip in quietly and prepare the feet of

Jesus,

for His burial. This she could do,

and was willing to do. There are many people like Mary in and about our churches. They do not want conspicoius places or positions. But

they are helping in other places. They do not seek credit, but God will see that they receive it.
